question.text: The standard electrode potentials <math> <mrow> <mfenced close=")" open="(" separators=","> <mrow> <msubsup> <mtext>E</mtext> <mrow> <msup> <mtext>M</mtext> <mo>+</mo> </msup> <mo>/</mo> <mtext>M</mtext> </mrow> <mtext>o</mtext> </msubsup> </mrow> </mfenced> </mrow> </math> of four metals <math> <mrow>  <mtext>A,</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>B,</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></math> and <math> <mtext>D</mtext></math> are <math> <mrow>  <mo>−</mo><mtext>1</mtext><mtext>.2</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>V,</mtext></mrow></math>, <math> <mrow>  <mtext>0</mtext><mtext>.6</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></math>, <math> <mrow>  <mtext>0</mtext><mtext>.85</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></math> and <math> <mrow>  <mo>−</mo><mtext>0</mtext><mtext>.76</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mtext>V</mtext></mrow></math>, respectively. The sequence of deposition of metals on applying potential is

solution.text:
In complete cation electrolysis at cathode, the species having higher reduction potential is preferably reduced at cathode
E C ∘ > E B ∘ > E D ∘ > E A ∘
Hence,  C > B > D > A
will be the preference of deposition of these metals on competeting.
